nobody likes
the child guesses I
For the child have a pocket-knife
" shouted Peter "
My father says
Mrs. Smith is always with the choir
" said Mrs. Reece "
seeing danger ahead
Ben means a family right here on the piazza
" The children looked at one another "
then Jack turned shrewdly to the guide
I guess flies
sir
it is flies
" Jack thought
he had never seen such a wonderful knife
It had three blades a corkscrew a file a pair of scissors "
to this day Jack has that knife
Come " said Mrs. Reece
" let
us all sit down for a few minutes
while Lizzie is getting supper ready inside
asked
" " How many wings " Mrs. Reece " has a
" " Four " answered Jimmie "
corrected
a real fly has only two wings
In the place of the second pair they have queer little knobbed rods
queer little knobbed rods are called balancers something like the out-riggers on your scull , Jim
These steer the fly body
These steady
" " What makes a fly bite
" asked Hope "
They do not bite child
A beetle a grasshopper can really bite
because beetles grasshoppers have heavy horny jaws toothed on the edge to do it
But a fly has fine sharp-pointed jaws
With these needlelike jaws
they pierce a hole in the skin then with a tiny sucking-beak , made by the rolled lower lip
made the rolled lower lip
they draw up the blood through this opening
" " I wonder
whether any little girl here knows
why flies should not be allowed in the house
" asked Mrs. Reece
No little girl did know anything "
except that their mothers were always driving flies out
that these creatures buzzed
were a
Do tell them "
said Mrs. Reece
_ A. _ House-fly
Well " said the guide
" the fly is such a little
it can crawl up the steepest most slippery wall
it walk upside down
it right side up with the greatest ease
you can make a fly
Perhaps some day keep still long enough so
that you can look at its foot
At the end of the foot are two little round pads
thickly covered with downy hair
On each side are two sharp claws many stiff clinging hairs
this flattened foot
it can go
wherever it wishes
" But this same little foot is the chief
why a fly should never be allowed in the house , for flies crawl into all sorts of dirty places
for flies
crawl into all sorts of dirty places
the fine hairs catch the dirt
the fine hairs hold
When the fly lights on us on the table some of the pieces of dirt are shaken off "
But they are so to catch
" " said Betty of the dining-room in the morning "
" it takes Lizzie forever forever to get them out
" I know
why they are to catch
" added Jack "
for I 've looked at a dead fly
They have such big eyes like lighthouses "
they can see all around
" Yes " said Ben Gile "
there is no such thing creeping up on a fly unawares
Flies are dirty " "
continued the old man
the time is not very far
when people will make war on them
just as they do on mosquitoes
Mrs. Fly lays her eggs in unclean places as many as a hundred eggs at a time
These eggs hatch out quickly
It takes only twenty-one days to make a chicken of an egg worms
out
a baby fly
it takes only a few hours ugly babies
to make they are little white worms
that live
that feed
that grow rapidly in dirty places
Within six days the maggot becomes a tiny dark-brown pupa "
after five days the pupa hatches out into a grown-up fly
A dozen little girls at the party made up their minds promptly
that after this evening they at least would make war on flies
" And are n't of any use "
asked Betty
" There is one little fly Mrs. Tachina-Fly
one little fly Mrs. Tachina-Fly is of some use
She is a of the house-fly
She is of use
because she chooses a queer place to lay her eggs on the back of a young caterpillar
After these caterpillars grow to change into a butterfly
these caterpillars shut themselves up into a cocoon
the little fly eggs hatch out into maggots
Of course they are
all babies are
finding the nice fat caterpillar in the round house like dutiful babies they eat
what is set before them
until the fat tender caterpillar is eaten up
After they are
they lie still in their brown skins
they change into grown-up tachina-flies
they at last out come a lot of busy , _ buzzing _
bothersome flies
It is rather on the caterpillar
when we think
what harmful greedy things most caterpillars are
But perhaps it is
that there are tachina-flies to eat them
Is it time for supper yet "
